question: <image 1>A transistor, which may be approximated as a hemispherical heat source of radius ro = 0.1 mm, is embedded in a large silicon substrate (k = 125 W/m$\cdot$  K) and dissipates heat at a rate q. All boundaries of the silicon are maintained at an ambient temperature of T$\infty$= 27C,except for the top surface, which is well insulated.evaluate the surface temperature of the heat source for q =4 W.
description:
The image depicts a schematic representation of a hemispherical heat source embedded within a silicon substrate. The heat source is shown as a hemisphere with a radius \( r_o \), which is specified to be 0.1 mm. This hemisphere is generating heat at a rate denoted by \( q \). The silicon substrate surrounding the heat source has a thermal conductivity \( k \) of 125 W/m·K. 

The top surface of the silicon substrate is well-insulated, meaning there is no heat transfer through this surface. All other boundaries of the silicon substrate are maintained at an ambient temperature \( T_\infty \), which is given as 27°C or 300 K. The question asks for the surface temperature of the hemispherical heat source when the heat dissipation rate \( q \) is 4 W. The options provided for the surface temperature are:

A. 340.93 K  
B. 350.93 K  
C. 360.93 K  

To solve this problem, one would need to use the appropriate heat conduction equation for a hemispherical heat source embedded in a semi-infinite medium with specified boundary conditions. The solution involves calculating the temperature rise due to the heat generation and adding it to the ambient temperature.
